name: Mylapore (San Thome)
shortDescription: The traditional site of Saint Thomas's martyrdom and burial in Chennai, India - home of San Thome Basilica, one of only three churches built over an apostle's tomb
fullDescription: Mylapore, now a neighborhood of Chennai (formerly Madras), holds profound significance in Christian tradition as the site where the apostle Thomas was martyred and buried around 72 CE. According to tradition, Thomas was killed by a spear thrust while praying at Little Mount (Chinnamalai), a small hill where he had retreated for meditation. His body was brought to the coast and buried at what is now San Thome Basilica, built directly over his tomb. The San Thome Basilica is one of only three churches in the world built over the tomb of an apostle - the others being St. Peter's Basilica in Rome and Santiago de Compostela in Spain. The Portuguese rebuilt the basilica in the 16th century after their arrival, and it was reconstructed in neo-Gothic style in 1893. The crypt beneath the main altar contains what tradition identifies as Thomas's tomb. Little Mount, about 8 kilometers away, preserves a cave where Thomas allegedly hid from persecutors, with a small aperture through which he is said to have escaped when discovered. The area also includes St. Thomas Mount (Parangi Malai), a larger hill where Thomas is believed to have been praying when struck by the spear. A bleeding cross allegedly carved by Thomas himself is venerated there. The martyrdom by spear carries profound theological resonance - Thomas, who demanded to see and touch Christ's spear wound, ultimately died by the same instrument, completing his journey from doubt to ultimate witness.

events.name: Martyrdom of Thomas (c. 72 CE)
events.description: Thomas was struck by a spear while praying at St. Thomas Mount. According to tradition, he was killed by order of the local king (Mazdai/Misdaeus in the Acts of Thomas) after converting members of the royal family to celibacy

events.name: Burial at Mylapore
events.description: Thomas's body was carried from St. Thomas Mount and buried at the coastal site that would become San Thome

events.name: Partial Translation of Relics to Edessa
events.description: Portions of Thomas's relics were transferred to Edessa, Syria, though the tomb remained in Mylapore

events.name: Portuguese Discovery
events.description: Portuguese colonizers arrived and 'discovered' the ancient tomb, confirming local traditions about Thomas

events.name: Construction of Portuguese Church
events.description: Portuguese built a new church over the tomb site

events.name: Current Basilica Construction
events.description: The present neo-Gothic San Thome Basilica was completed

events.name: Minor Basilica Status
events.description: San Thome was elevated to Minor Basilica status by Pope Pius XII

sacredSites.name: San Thome Basilica
sacredSites.description: Minor basilica built directly over Thomas's tomb. The crypt beneath the main altar contains the tomb. One of only three churches built over an apostle's tomb (with St. Peter's and Santiago de Compostela)
features: Museum with Thomas relics and artifacts

sacredSites.name: Little Mount (Chinnamalai)
sacredSites.description: Small hill about 8 km from San Thome where Thomas retreated for prayer. Contains cave with small aperture through which Thomas is said to have escaped
features: Chapel of Our Lady of Health

sacredSites.name: St. Thomas Mount (Parangi Malai)
sacredSites.description: 135-foot hill where Thomas was allegedly martyred. Contains the 'bleeding cross' allegedly carved by Thomas himself
features: Bleeding cross relic (said to exude moisture)

theBleedingCross.description: A stone cross allegedly carved by Thomas himself, preserved at St. Thomas Mount
theBleedingCross.tradition: The cross is said to have 'bled' on December 18, 1558, and has periodically exuded moisture since
theBleedingCross.inscription: Pahlavi (Middle Persian) inscription around the cross
theBleedingCross.significance: One of several Thomas relics venerated in Chennai; connects to Indo-Persian Christian tradition

textReferences.context: Narrates Thomas's martyrdom at command of King Misdaeus

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Mylapore represents the completion of Thomas's journey from doubt to ultimate witness. The spear that killed him echoes the spear wound of Christ that he demanded to see. His tomb beneath a basilica places him among the most honored apostles. The site symbolizes Christianity's reach to the 'ends of the earth' and the blood of martyrs as seed of the church.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: San Thome Basilica draws pilgrims from around the world, especially from India's Mar Thoma Christian communities. The site anchors Indian Christian identity, providing tangible connection to apostolic origins. The July 3 feast day brings special celebrations. The bleeding cross and other relics inspire ongoing devotion.
